bibl.title: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to William E. Deeks, August 28, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] believes that malaria is best controlled by attacking mosquitoes and explains why. He notes that community sterilization of malaria carriers by quinine is a recognized method advocated by physicians, but not by entomologists.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to William E. Deeks, August 28, 1923
div1.opener:
August 28, 1923.
Dr. W. E. Deeks, General Manager,
Medical Department, United Fruit Company,
17 Battery Place,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Deeks:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of August 22nd., I would say that the com-
munity sterilization of malaria carriers by quinine is a recognized method
of malaria control. In all places it can be used as an adjuvant and in
some places may be the method of election. The same method, of course,
is not equally applicable to all communities.

My own feeling is in general for the control by lessening Ano-
pheles production where this is economically practicable. In some places
it is not.

There are a few things in the method by sterilization of car-
riers I would ask you to note:

1/ If the work be undertaken while infected Anopheles are
in flight, not only must all carriers be freed from parasites, but the
quinine must be continued (I do not say in the same dose) long enough to
prevent their reinfection while they are still exposed to infected Ano-
pheles. This, I am quite sure, was the reason for the continuation of the
treatment by Koch at Stephansort for some weeks after the disappearance of
parasites in the blood--although he does not mention it as a reason in his
report, simply states that he did continue the treatment for some time.

2/ If one wants permanent results in a community--not simply
for a single season--very obviously steps must be taken to prevent immi-
gration into this community of people infected outside of it.

The reason that Bass' work in Bolivar County was so non-perma-
nent was because his community consisted mainly of negro tenant farmers
farmers
renting by the year and something over 60% of the community was changed
after the crop was gathered.

In Mitchell County, Ga., the result was more lasting: the community
consisting of white farmers handling and working their own little places,
so there was little change of population at the end of the year.

Koch's report, and the method used at Stephansort and in German
East-Africa, implies that he consideres the inability to find parasites
in the cutaneous blood after a single careful examination as proof that the
patient is freeffrom them. It is, of course, untenable. The observations
of many British Commissions during the war showed that a man might be nega-
tive for parasites on more than one careful examination and yet be infected.
In this connection I would especially note the work of Acton et al at Dagahai.
It was p published in the Indian Journal of Research about two years ago. You
do not, however, need any warning on that ground.

The treatment most advisable--i. e. the dosage and method of ad-
ministration of quinine--you can tell better than anyone else. You know
what other men have used and with what results and you can make your own ob-
servations upon carriers under good control--observing both parasite and
symptomatic relapse--and will be able to give us very valuable information
as to the choice of method for the use of quinine as well as important data
as to the immediate efficacy: the permanent efficacy and the cost of this gener-
al method, on which exact extensive knowledge is lacking.

Without question it will--at the very least--be of assistance to
you in malaria control even if you use it combined with other methods.

I note that Orenstein reported against its efficientcy at Dar-es-
Salaam when he went there soon after he left Panama. It is, as you know--
and naturally--the method most generally advocated by physicians and en-
entirely reprobated by entomologists.
